The round of the nose is indeed exponentially & incrementally veering the projectile away from the matches as it collided with each consecutive match head, as you stated, so, counter it with a parabola - I think if you graduate each match slightly higher than it's predecessor along the strike path, the projectile will ride up the curve and potentially be allowed to actually strike each head..  just sayin.. maybe give it a try & show what happens if you get a chance..  Oh, too, I envision using a 'parabolic' curve to accommodate the gradated trajectory deflecting upward as it both slows & slightly succumbs to the multi impacts (a little more resistance influence by each match head along the path)..  this way, I can see all match heads getting struck in the one shot...

Good luck if you try.. but do mention me a credit somewhere if you try it & it works!

The correct way to say it is the "momentum transfer to the can is less with a .223 than a .22".  Basically, a slower round imparts more energy sometimes because it doesn't zip through the material as fast, dragging the material more along the way.
